content.rendered:
CBD FAQ's

Frequently Asked Question!

What is CBD (Cannabidiol)?

Cannabidiol (CBD) is a product that is obtained from hemp, or more precisely, Cannabis Sativa L. plants.

Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), another component also found in hemp plants, is psychoactive and responsible for the state of the narcotic effect. CBD, on the other hand, is not a psychoactive substance; moreover, it carries a lot of therapeutic benefits. These properties are different from medical marijuana, which is used as a pain reliever and to alleviate symptoms in patients. CBD oil is a hemp extract collected from legitimate hemp varieties.

The content of THC in such a product does not exceed the statutory limit of 0.2 – 0.3%. For example, to obtain a mild narcotic effect, you need to use about 6-9 litres of hemp oil at a time!

There is some controversy surrounding hemp products, such as CBD oil, over the use of marijuana to create drugs. But also, there’s a growing awareness of the benefits of CBD oils for health.

How CBD works?

In order to understand how CBD functions, you first need to get a grasp of the endocannabinoid system. Discovered a couple of decades back, the system consists of naturally occurring cannabinoids and cannabinoid receptor sites throughout the body. This biological system has been found to be responsible for various functions in our body that regulate a variety of physiological and cognitive processes. Some of these functions include appetite, fertility, memory and even emotional behavior. In short, it’s our body’s protection system that guards us against both external and internal stressors. It comes into play when our body’s delicate inner balance is affected and helps in getting it back to equilibrium.

 

The cannabis has been found to contain compounds known as phytocannabinoids. When ingested, they mimic the activity of our naturally produced endocannabinoids. These cannabinoids perfectly fit into our cannabinoid receptors and alter our endocannabinoid system in many different ways. CB1 and CB2 are the two receptors that make up the system. CB1 receptors are mostly found in the nervous system, glands, and connective tissues, whereas CB2 receptors are primarily found in the immune system of the body. The primary way in which CBD works is that it signals the body’s natural endogenous cannabinoids to activate those receptors and gets them to perform better. As these cannabinoid receptors are spread throughout our body, the importance of CBD of having these receptors and the internal system functioning optimally is highly commendable.

What are the benefits of CBD?

As we’ve mentioned, CBD, unlike THC, is not psychoactive. This quality makes CBD an attractive option for those who are looking for good pain management treatment and relief of other symptoms, without causing harm to the mental health of the person.

It is becoming incredibly popular in the field of health and well-being; many studies confirm its beneficial properties. Here are some of the main benefits of CBD oil that are backed by scientific evidence.

Is CBD legal?

The answer to whether CBD is legal or illegal depends on one crucial factor, and that is the source it is derived from–hemp or marijuana. While hemp and marijuana are both members of the cannabis family and share a lot of characteristics, there is a fundamental difference between the two, which is the amount of psychoactive Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) each plant produces. While marijuana can contain up to 30% THC, hemp contains no more than 0.3% THC. In other words, using marijuana in any form can get you high. However, the negligible amount of THC in hemp makes it impossible to get high off it. So, as hemp has no psychoactive effects, its consumption is not illegal, and so the consumption, purchase, sales, or possession of “hemp-derived” CBD is completely legal in all 50 States, enjoying the same rights of any other legal product.

Does it matter where my CBD is sourced from?

It’s always essential to get to know about the source of your CBD, especially if you’re buying it online. Usually, potency and purity are some of the significant factors that contribute to making your CBD authentic, and when it’s sourced from a licensed medical cannabis dispensary, the chances of it being a genuine product are much higher. Again, states that have legalized recreational and medical cannabis require all CBD products to be tested by an accredited lab and labeled accordingly. So, checking the CBD’s source before you decide to consume it is an important initial step that shouldn’t be missed.   

How do you consume CBD?

CBD is available in many forms such as tinctures, soft gel capsules, vape liquid, chewable gummies, etc. You can choose the one that suits your lifestyle and necessity. If you wish to apply it on your body, then you can go for the liquid form. But, if you want to consume it on the move, then chewable gummies can be ideal. Else, you can go for the Soft gel capsules that can be swallowed with water like any other medicine.

Difference between Hemp oil and CBD oil?

Though the seeds from any plant in the cannabis family can be used to produce hemp oil, it is primarily derived from the industrial hemp. The seeds contain almost 50% oil and so it can be extracted easily. The hemp oil from hemp seeds high amounts of polyunsaturated fats like Omega-6 and Omega-3 fatty acids, as well as Vitamin E, and so is usually preferred for its nutritional value rather than as a medicine.

 

CBD oil is extracted from the leaves, stalks, and buds of hemp plants. Strains with high CBD levels are carefully chosen in order to maximize the potency of the end product. While there different ways to extract the oil, the safest is the oil-based method, where the plant is soaked in a carrier lubricant, such as hemp or olive oil, which helps in splitting the components. Another alternative is the CO2-based approach, which places the material under high pressure. The end product is the oil that is rich in CBD with no psychoactive effects. The oil has been found to have many medicinal and therapeutic uses and can be used to treat epilepsy and psychological problems, apart from aiding in treating cancer and acting as an anti-inflammatory substance.

 

Cannabidiol (CBD) is one of the many cannabinoids identified in cannabis. The Cannabis plant is a genus of florae in the Cannabaceae family. Cannabis can be used as an extract and is also known as hemp. However, hemp is the term that refers only to the variety cultivated for non-drug use.

 

The CBD is a major phyto-cannabinoid, which can make up 40% of the plant’s extract. CBD does not have intoxicating effects like those caused by tetra-hydro-cannabinol (THC), which is its more popular cousin. On the other hand, it has been found to have many medicinal applications, such as having a positive impact on thinking disorders and anxiety.
